Trial_Design.evidence: Residents were then randomized with 10 receiving additional training with the Procedicus, computer-based, haptic simulator.

Participants.evidence: Twenty general surgery residents received didactic training in the techniques of catheter intervention.

Intervention.evidence: Residents were then randomized with 10 receiving additional training with the Procedicus, computer-based, haptic simulator.

Objective.evidence: we explored whether simulation might impact the acquisition of catheter skills by surgical residents.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Resident performance was graded by attending surgeons blinded to the resident's training status, using 18 procedural steps as well as a global rating scale.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Residents were then randomized with 10 receiving additional training with the Procedicus, computer-based, haptic simulator.

Blinding.evidence: Resident performance was graded by attending surgeons blinded to the resident's training status

Number_Randomised.evidence: Residents were then randomized with 10 receiving additional training with the Procedicus, computer-based, haptic simulator.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Overall, residents exposed to simulation scored higher than controls during the first angio/OR intervention: procedural steps (simulation/control) (50 ± 6 vs. 33 ± 9, P = 0.0015); global rating scale (30 ± 7 vs. 19 ± 5, P = 0.0052).
